executive_summary: The Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry is anticipated to grow over the five years to 2021. This growth has been primarily driven by rising demand from private households increasingly redecorating and improving homes in recent years. Further demand stems from commercial entities as they have increasingly improved office space. Among private consumers, increased housing starts and purchasing power in the form of enhanced disposable income levels have fostered enhanced expenditures on home furnishings, such as curtains and drapes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry operators have benefited from a strong housing market during the five-year period. Over the five years to 2021, housing starts have risen at an annualized rate of 5.5%. As home builders construct more houses and people buy more homes, the demand for new curtains and drapes increases, helping to bolster industry revenue.

Operators also generate demand from other commercial entities. As the number of businesses has increased, a greater number of used offices and storefronts have been equipped with upgraded newer furnishing and decorations, thus boosting demand for curtains and drapes.

Industry profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to account for 2.6% of revenue in 2021, down from 4.6% in 2016. Despite strong demand and slight revenue growth, increased sales have not been enough to offset the effect of rising input prices.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Macroeconomic conditions are anticipated to rebound following the coronavirus pandemic and remain strong over the course of the outlook period. This trend should help to bolster industry demand moving forward.

As employment levels and disposable income remain high, developers are likely to produce more housing units while consumers are likely to increase spending on home improvements. In 2021, the residential sector is expected to account for 70.7% of industry revenue.

While input prices are set to modestly rise, the rate of industry revenue growth is forecast to be stalled over the five years to 2026. As a result, industry profitability is estimated to remain largely stable.

The expected favorable trade conditions characteristic of the five years to 2026 will likely help foster this accelerated revenue growth. The industry is expected to benefit from relatively strong international demand for high value-added industry products.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures window curtains and draperies from purchased fabrics or sheet goods. The curtains and draperies may be made on a stock or custom basis for sale to individual retail customers.

mixed_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: medium - steady

key_trends: Industry operators have benefited from a strong housing market during the period
Increased sales have not been enough to offset rising input prices
Industry exports have suffered due to heightened price competitiveness
Strong residential spending is expected to drive demand for curtains
Anticipated growth in industry exports is expected to support revenue growth

market_segmentation.segment_description: Residential customers account for an estimated 70.7% of revenue in 2021. As curtains and drapes are discretionary in nature, demand for industry products follows closely with household incomes.
Consumers whose earnings are more than $100,000 annually represent the largest market for the Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry, accounting for an estimated 39.8% of revenue in 2021.
IBISWorld anticipates consumers earning between $40,000 to $100,000 to make up 19.5% of industry revenue.

Industry operators also supply curtains and draperies to commercial markets, including hospitality, healthcare, education and performing arts industries. Commercial customers account for an estimated 19.2% of industry revenue in 2021.
Income earners making less than $40,000 annually account for an estimated 11.4% of industry revenue.
Exports are expected to account for 10.1% of industry revenue in 2021.

products_and_services.product_description: Ready-made curtain panels made of all types of fabric, such as cotton, rayon, acetate, linen, polyester, olefin, glass and other fibers.

Despite draperies and curtains share several similar characteristics, draperies are slightly different as they are generally made of heavyweight fabrics, such as velvet and brocade, and come with lining.
Tailored made curtains and drapes are generally more expensive, making demand for this segment largely dependent on the levels of household and business wealth.

tier_2_suppliers: Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Dye & Pigment Manufacturing in the US
Synthetic Fiber Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US
Arts, Entertainment and Recreation in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: A downturn in housing construction activity can reduce the number of potential houses that demand curtains and drapes, thus lowering industry revenue.

Industry operators also supply curtains and draperies to nonresidential buildings such as hospitals, theaters, schools and hotels. Therefore, a slowdown in the nonresidential construction market can dampen demand for curtains, directly affecting industry revenue.

The level of per capita disposable income affects demand for housing renovation activities. A higher income level enables consumers to increase their expenditures on home improvements, bolstering demand for new curtains and drapes.
When corporate profit rises, companies are more willing to spend on upgrading or replacing old curtains; conversely, they are more likely to restrain installing new curtains when budgets are tight.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Imported curtains and drapes are anticipated to account for 50.8% of domestic demand for the Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry in 2021. The United States primarily imports industry relevant goods from China, India Pakistan and Mexico.

The largest destination for industry exports is Canada, which is estimated to account for 54.8% of industry exports. The second-largest industry export market is Mexico, which is anticipated to account for 24.4% in 2021.

business_locations.location_description: Establishments in the Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry are highly concentrated in the Southeast region of the United States. In 2021, this region is expected to account for 31.3% of industry establishments. Florida and North Carolina contain 8.6% and 6.1% of the industry's establishments, respectively.

Textile mills are also concentrated in the West; the region has the second-largest share of industry establishments with 16.1%. California, in particular, houses the majority of these with 11.8% of the nation's total, the highest of any individual state.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry must comply with several environmental laws pertaining to discharges into the air and waterways, storage and disposal of chemicals, and disposal of waste and by-products.
Industry operators must adhere to labor and wage laws, occupational health and safety regulations related to machinery guards, noise control, and cotton dust controls.

The Window Covering Manufacturers Association has imposed a new safety standard requiring all stock window covering products in the US to be cordless or have inaccessible/short cords to prevent strangulation hazards.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Major starting costs include purchases of sewing machines and fabrics. Fabrics that are mainly used in making draperies such as brocade, velvet, damask and silk usually come at high price tags.
As industry operators endure high competition, marketing plays a vital role in differentiating one from another, thus helping to ease the degree of competition.
Established relationships with downstream customers and suppliers might represent another barrier to new market players.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry is highly fragmented with no dominant industry player. As such, industry players compete vigorously based on price, quality, service and product range.

The price of curtains and drapes is a major source of competition among companies operating within this industry. Any industry operators that can price products more competitively than competitors will likely to win more customers.

While curtain and drape are used for home improvement purposes, demand for their materials and shades vary significantly, therefore operators that offer a high-quality and wide range of curtains and drapes are at an advantage.
Operators in the Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry also competes with other substitutes such as shades and blinds, which have wide applications in office buildings.
Besides, domestic industry operators have to compete with foreign curtain and drape manufacturers. In specific, more than half of domestic demand is captured by imported curtains.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry comprises 1,082 enterprises in 2021. On average, an industry operator employs less than 10 people, implying that industry operators are mostly small-scale establishments.

The low to moderate entry barrier has enabled individuals to easily enter the market and operate as nonemployers. Consequently, nonemployers account for a large share of industry operators, making the industry fragmented.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The major component of a company's expenses is purchases, which include textiles and materials from upstream industries. Purchases are expected to account for 61.8% of industry revenue in 2021. Purchases' share of revenue has remained relatively stable during the five-year period.
In 2021, wage costs are estimated to comprise 22.8% of industry revenue in 2021, a slight increase from the 21.8% in 2016. This share indicates that the industry is moderately labor-intensive.
Depreciation, which indicates industry operators' capital costs, is expected to account for 1.1% of industry revenue in 2021, remaining stable throughout the period.
Marketing costs for this industry is expected to account for 0.1% of revenue in 2021. Overall, industry operators are best served by a reputation for quality work and fair prices.
Industry rent is expected to account for 0.8% of industry revenue in 2021, as operators tend to own facilities and equipment used in the production process.
Industry utilities costs are expected to account for 1.5% of industry revenue in 2021, remaining largely stable throughout the period.

Other industry expenses include transportation costs, legal fees and administrative costs, in addition to insurance costs and premiums, which are collectively expected to account for 9.4% of revenue in 2021.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry exhibits a low level of capital intensity. On average, the industry spends $0.05 on capital, for every dollar spent on labor.
Companies make capital expenditures on improvements and replacements of industry equipment and machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry exhibits a moderate amount of revenue volatility due to shifts in demand from home makers and offices during the period.
Preferences for certain styles, materials, textures and colors change often and have contributed to overall volatility and variability in demand for industry goods.
Volatility can also be caused by disruptions in the supply inputs, such as certain synthetic fibers and cotton, to industry operators.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry has increasingly relied on technology over the past decades, adopting industrial sewing machines, automated pleats sewing machines, and other automated machines to produce at a larger scale and more sophisticated curtain designs.

Over the five years to 2021, there is a rising threat from smart home trends, in which consumers favor the use of automatic blinds and shades, which are expected to emerge as a disruptive force to the industry.

FAQs.question: Companies across the industry manufacture a range of products. Does your company produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies that offer a various range of goods tend to do well. Companies offer knit and woven curtains and drapes tend to do well.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the housing market?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies benefit from a strong housing market. A strong housing market means more homes are being built, and even more are being renovated. The industry generates the majority of its revenue from residential markets, so a strong housing market really helps our performance.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to rising input costs over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Our most significant industry input, synthetic fiber has experienced a price rise over the last five years. This has hurt industryl profitability throughout the period.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Companies that have practiced acquisition strategies have performed strongly and gained market concentration.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: There has been a rising focus to develop technologies that minimize waste and pollutants. Investment into environmentally friendly materials to reduce carpet trim waste has become an increasingly significant element of companies in the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Sales are driven by the introduction of new products to the market, and disruptive technological advances drive product development. Beside product introduction, technological advancements can reduce long term manufacturing costs.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: EPA regulations surrounding manufacturing are constantly evolving. Noncompliance with regulatory controls such as environmental laws can carry heavy penalties, including revocation of permits, corrective action orders, administrative or civil penalties and criminal prosecution.

FAQs.question: Have you had any regulatory expenses that have significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Some regulatory expenses are US customs duties for imported synthetic fibers, yarns and other materials. Further expenses include regulations to discharges into the air and waterways, storage and disposal of chemicals and disposal of waste and byproducts. Good companies have learned to navigate to stay profitable.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Increasing prices of synthetic fiber has hindered industry operators ability to generate higher margins.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Most houses are built and sold, and more renovations and redecorating take place in the warmer spring and summer months. This seasonality can hurt operators over the winter.

FAQs.question: How close are you to your suppliers? How else can you cut down on transportation costs?
FAQs.answer: Being within a short distance of input suppliers (e.g. textile machinery suppliers or fiber suppliers) can alleviate potential logistical problems and cut down on transportation costs.

FAQs.question: Do you have fixed, long-term supply contracts for key inputs? How else to you guard against input price fluctuations?
FAQs.answer: Companies that secure contracts for fixed prices for inputs are protected from price volatility, which can affect cotton markets in particular.

FAQs.question: Have you made investments in automated machinery? How else can you leverage economies of scale?
FAQs.answer: Companies that can reduce the marginal cost of the products they produce have a competitive advantage. Investing in highly automated machinery is usually the way operators do this.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your revenue is generated from the residential construction sector? How can you take
FAQs.answer: More than 70.0% of revenue is generated from residential sector.

FAQs.question: Housing starts
FAQs.answer: Housing starts affect demand for curtains and drapes from the residential housing sector because as more people buy homes, they are more inclined to purchase decor such as industry products. Therefore, an increase in the number of new housing units typically increase industry demand.

FAQs.question: Per capita disposable income
FAQs.answer: Higher per capita disposable income can often encourage customers to spend more on remodeling and redecorating, which often lead to the purchasing of newer curtains. In addition, customers with more income are more likely to opt for more expensive industry goods, benefiting industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Private spending on home improvements
FAQs.answer: Private spending on home improvements, upgrades and repairs affects demand for products produced by the Curtain and Drape Manufacturing industry. Private spending on home improvements has increased over the past five years, driven by increased per capita disposable income and increased home sales.
